executive_summary: The Franchise Resale Brokers and Consultants industry has grown over the five years to 2021 largely due to favorable credit markets and steady economic growth. Over the past five years, growth in the number of US businesses and greater private investment in the economy have helped increase both the availability of and demand for franchises. However, the industry also encountered a significant slowdown in business during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic as more prospective franchise owners put off investing in a new franchise until after the macroeconomy demonstrates signs of recovery. As a result, industry revenue is only expected to increase at an annualized rate of 0.2% to $93.5 million over the five years to 2021. IBISWorld estimates revenue to grow 5.4% in 2021 alone as low interest rates and a recovering macroeconomic environment spurs franchise-buying activity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Despite strong revenue growth, industry profit contracted
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite the industry experiencing strong revenue growth for most of the current period, IBISWorld estimates average industry profit to contract over the five years to 2021. Industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is projected to account for 9.9% of revenue in 2021, down from 11.1% in 2016. This level remains in the range of the industry's historical rates of profitability, which exhibits minor fluctuations in line with revenue. The primary driver of the industry's shrinking profitability is due to recent increases in operating costs and lower demand for industry services which have materialized during the global health crisis.

The Franchise Resale Brokers and Consultants industry provides business development services, research and informational services on behalf of franchisors to prospective franchise business owners. Over the five years to 2021, the industry has experienced moderate growth. The industry's main drivers including consumer spending, aggregate private investment and the number of businesses operating in the United States. Growth in the number of businesses is a vital determinant of industry revenue because an increase in the number of businesses leads to greater franchise opportunities, increasing demand for franchise brokers to sell new franchises.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Successful franchise sales drive industry revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since franchise brokers are primarily paid a commission from franchisors upon the successful sale of a business, an increase in the number of franchise sales drives revenue for industry operators. These commissions and other fees related to marketing or consultation are the basis for industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Positive economic factors supported franchise expansion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Increased aggregate private investment in the economy, and greater access to credit, has contributed to greater franchise purchases and greater commissions and fees for franchise brokers and consultants. The expansion of franchises has been further enabled by an increase in consumer spending that has supported many consumer-facing franchisors, increasing an annualized 2.4% over the five years to 2021. Many consumer-facing retail establishments thrive within the franchise business model. Hence, increased consumer spending supports franchise revenue growth, increasing profitability and incentivizing franchise expansion.

However, nearly every franchised business has encountered significant setbacks since the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak as socioeconomic restrictions forced many small businesses and entrepreneurial ventures to shutter. As a result, industry revenue is expected to only increase an annualized 0.2% to $93.5 million over the five years to 2021, including an increase of 5.4% in 2021 alone. This growth includes a 10.3% decline in revenue in 2020 due to a sharp reduction in aggregate private investment and macroeconomic activity that same year.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Strong industry growth expected over next 5 years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Franchise Resale Brokers and Consultants industry is anticipated to experience strong growth over the five years to 2026 as the global business environment continues to recover from the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. A strong domestic economy, characterized by consumer spending increasing an annualized 2.5% over the five years to 2026 and aggregate private investment increasing an annualized 3.0% during the same period, is expected to fuel industry demand. Furthermore, as corporate profit improves, more businesses are anticipated to seek franchising opportunities to further expand operations. In turn, industry revenue is anticipated to increase an annualized 2.4% to $105.1 million over the five years 2026.

The industry is anticipated to experience sustained enterprise and employment growth. New enterprise growth is expected to primarily be driven by projected increases in aggregate private investment and greater access to credit to finance franchise purchases. As aggregate private investment increases, investors are willing to invest in franchise businesses. Rising access to credit will likely enable individuals to raise capital for franchise purchases. Therefore, the number of industry enterprises is expected to grow an annualized 1.5% to 354 over the five years to 2026.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry employment and wages to rise
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As franchisors put more franchise opportunities up for sale, industry operators will likely need to expand their capacity for brokering new deals. Thus, industry employment is expected to rise to service higher demand for franchise brokerage. Industry employment is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 2.0% to 1,166 employees over the five years to 2026. Similarly, industry wages are also expected to increase an annualized 2.0% to $35.8 million during the same period.

industry_definition: This industry includes salesmen and brokers that provide introduction services for franchise opportunity sellers with whom they have worked out pay-for-sale agreements. In addition to advice, companies in this industry may also offer franchise research, education and other informational services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Increasing employment, disposable income and consumer spending supports expansion of consumer-facing businesses and franchises.
Lending to small businesses and access to credit facilitate franchise purchases.
Poor economic conditions reduce consumer capital, lending and interest in franchises.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region holds the highest concentration of industry establishments, matching its large population.
The West region has a slightly higher concentration of establishments compared to its population share.
The Mid-Atlantic region's share of establishments closely matches its population share.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry is regulated by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). The FTC publishes the Franchise Rule, which defines what constitutes unfair or deceptive, and therefore illegal, practices in the franchise industry.
In response to the coronavirus outbreak, federal, state and local policymakers imposed regulations on many public and business activities that contributed to business disruptions in the industry.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, presenting a barrier to entry.
There is no industry assistance, which is a steady barrier.
The industry has high concentration, which is a barrier.

factors_decreased_barrier.factor: The industry has low capital intensity, decreasing barriers.
The industry has light and steady regulation, decreasing barriers.
The industry has low technology change, decreasing barriers.
The industry has low and steady globalization, decreasing barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: Participants compete based on area of expertise, connection to downstream franchisors and reputation. Many brokers serve limited areas, competing directly with local brokers. Some national networks have branch offices competing across regions.

Franchise brokers face limited competition from business brokers offering franchise consulting services. Online marketplaces allow franchisors to sell without brokers, but many still prefer using brokers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry exhibits moderate-to-high market share concentration. The four largest operators account for 69.3% of revenue in 2021.
Some large operators benefit from economies of scale through franchisor relationships, while many smaller local operators have limited scale economies.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages account for largest share of revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages, which include commissions on sales, are estimated to account for 34.6% of industry revenue in 2021, marking a decrease from 39.1% of revenue in 2016.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases minimal due to service-based nature
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are estimated to account for 3.4% of industry revenue in 2021. Given the service-based nature of industry operations, the industry's purchases are minimal.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Marketing expenses significant for attracting clients
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Marketing expenses are estimated to account for 2.4% of industry revenue in 2021. Industry operators, especially independent franchise brokers, must spend a significant amount on marketing to attract franchisors for franchise listings and potential franchisees.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rent costs for office and facility improvements
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Rental expenses are projected to account for 3.2% of industry revenue in 2021. As a method to attract new clients, franchise brokers commonly invest in office and facility improvements.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other costs include insurance, professional fees, dues
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs for industry operators include insurance costs, professional service fees, association dues and legal fees, among others. Overall, other costs are estimated to account for 45.9% of industry revenue in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: For every $1.00 spent on labor, only $0.02 is spent on capital.
As a sales-based industry, a sizeable share of industry operating costs is dedicated to hiring skilled and experienced brokers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Some capital investment on offices and IT
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Franchise brokers and consulting firms do make some capital investments, primarily on office locations and information technology equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for franchise broker services normally fluctuates in line with the business cycle; increasing consumer spending increases profitability of various businesses in the economy and leads to greater franchise expansion.
Industry revenue largely grew at a stable rate for most of the current period as strong macroeconomic growth spurred demand for franchise broker services, minimizing industry revenue volatility.

Industry revenue volatility picked up substantially in the second half of the current period as the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic authored widespread business disruptions and led to a severe decline in the number of active businesses as economic activity shuttered.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry does not experience technological disruption due to the expertise and person-to-person nature of industry services.
Industry operators rely on experience and relationships to deliver consultations and broker businesses, and such expertise is difficult to supplant with technology.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Online services for wider market reach
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Online services have helped operators reach a wider market for their services, but have offered little in the way of cost efficiencies.

FAQs.question: How do you communicate the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Brokers are useful to franchisors by providing access to a network of potential franchisees. Brokers are also useful by connecting qualified franchisees with a network of potential franchisors.

FAQs.question: How has the shift toward conducting business online affected demand for your services? How has your company responded to the widespread stay-at-home orders that have shut down large swaths of in-person business?
FAQs.answer: The industry has experienced rising competition from online franchise brokerages. External competition also comes from online research resources that provide some of the same information industry operators provide.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to reduce costs?
FAQs.answer: Wage costs make up the majority of expenses for franchise brokers and consultants.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are they more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: Franchise brokers and consultants are spread around the country and typically align with general population distribution. They are more concentrated in the Southeast, West, and Mid-Atlantic regions.

FAQs.question: What methods have you adopted to improve cash flow in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry have diversified their range of services to include strategy, legal, and operational consulting services for franchisors.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry struggle to protect against seasonality, as each company usually targets a very specific region and type of franchisee. Therefore, it is difficult for companies in the industry to diversify their target market.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? What range does your company have in terms of viable operating area?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must be located near a source of prospective franchisees.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation with clients? How can you build up such a reputation? What is your prior success rate?
FAQs.answer: Operators must be able to demonstrate an established track record in successfully matching prospective franchisees with franchises.

FAQs.question: What processes are in place for your company to check the financial status of your clients? How can you improve?
FAQs.answer: A primary duty of industry operators is assessing the financial health of prospective franchisees to ensure they can successfully start a franchise.

FAQs.question: How do you measure trends in consumer spending? How is your business affected when the level of consumer spending changes?
FAQs.answer: An increase in consumer spending generally leads to an increase in revenue and operating income for retail stores, restaurants and consumer service businesses, many of which operate as franchises.

FAQs.question: How will your company respond to an expected increase in the number of US businesses? Does your revenue trend in line with business formation?
FAQs.answer: The number of US businesses, especially the total number of franchises, is important to the industry because franchise businesses or franchisors are the primary clients for franchise brokering and consulting services.

FAQs.question: How can you take advantage when access to credit increases? Do you monitor banks' ability to lend to individuals and businesses?
FAQs.answer: An increase in access to credit, measured by the ability of commercial banks to lend to individuals and businesses, tends to remove barriers related to franchise and small business ownership.
